item.title: Middle East Crisis: Live Updates: Muted Reactions to Israeli Strikes on Iran Hint at De-Escalation
item.description: Israel had vowed retaliation for Iran’s attack last weekend, but the strikes reported overnight were limited, and Iran downplayed them.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians at an anti-Israel rally after Friday prayers in Tehran on Friday.

item.title: Worried About Trump’s Support for Ukraine, Eastern Europe Tries Outreach
item.description: A gathering of officials from Lithuania and Ukraine and supporters of Donald J. Trump highlights growing efforts to get on the good side of the former U.S. president in case he is elected again.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Tomas Dapkus
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump at the CPAC Convention in February. European leaders are seeking to plan for a possible second Trump presidency.

item.title: Ukrainians Wait, Nervously, to See if U.S. Will Provide Critical Aid
item.description: From the battlefield to battered cities, soldiers and civilians are counting on Congress to approve $60 billion in military support. Without it, Ukrainian officials say, its prospects in the war are grim.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Maria Varenikova and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers of Ukraine’s 32nd Mechanized Brigade in the Kharkiv region this month.

item.title: Turkey Earthquake Trial Opens Amid Anger and Tears
item.description: More than 300 people were killed when temblors toppled an upscale residential complex. Survivors hope a court will punish the men who built it.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new trial aims to seek accountability for the deadly collapse of Renaissance Residence, near the Turkish city of Antakya, during an earthquake last year.

item.title: Forbidden to Watch Films as a Child, He Now Directs Somalia’s Top Shows
item.description: Abshir Rageh had to sneak out from home to see bootleg Indian films and “Rambo” at a makeshift cinema. Now, he’s creating dramas that draw millions of online views in a country inching toward stability.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abshir Rageh, in red shirt and cap, on the set of a TV drama he’s filming in Mogadishu, Somalia.

item.title: Why India’s Opposition Can’t Get It Together
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party got less than 40% of the vote in the last election. But his fractured and dysfunctional rivals have struggled to capitalize on that.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: An Indian National Congress rally in Mandya, India, on Wednesday. The party governed India for decades, but those days are long gone.

item.title: Modi’s Power Keeps Growing, and India Looks Sure to Give Him More
item.description: Few doubt the popular prime minister will win a third term in voting that starts Friday. His strong hand is just what many Indians seem to want.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: To Narendra Modi’s legions of supporters, he is a magnetic figure and a powerful orator, with an image as a tireless, incorruptible worker for India.

item.title: Miscalculation Led to Escalation in Clash Between Israel and Iran
item.description: Israeli officials say they didn’t see a strike on a high-level Iranian target in Syria as a provocation, and did not give Washington a heads-up about it until right before it happened.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: The Iranian Embassy complex in Damascus, Syria, a day after an airstrike by Israel.

item.title: U.S. Restarts Deportation Flights to Haiti
item.description: The Biden administration had paused deportations of Haitian migrants in recent months as their home country was wracked by violence.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:description: Cars burned in gang violence in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last month.

item.title: Rainstorms Kill More Than 130 in Afghanistan and Pakistan
item.description: Pakistani officials warned of more flooding and heavy rainfall next week, stoking fears of a particularly brutal monsoon season to come.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: In Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province, the area of Pakistan that appeared to be hardest hit by the rainfall, on Tuesday.

item.title: Germany Arrests 2 Men Suspected of Spying for Russia
item.description: The two men, dual citizens of both countries, were accused of being part of a plot to undermine aid to Ukraine by trying to blow up military infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Outside a court in Karlsruhe, Germany, on Thursday. Federal prosecutors based in the city said one of the men had considered a U.S. military base as one of several potential targets.

item.title: Dubai’s Extraordinary Flooding: Here’s What to Know
item.description: Images of a saturated desert metropolis startled the world, prompting talk of cloud seeding, climate change and designing cities for intensified weather.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Abandoned vehicles in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, on Thursday.

item.title: 3 Reasons This Country Is a Top ISIS Recruiting Ground
item.description: Hundreds of Tajik men have joined an Islamic State affiliate, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered outside Crocus City Hall outside Moscow after the terrorist attack there last month. Russia charged four migrant laborers from Tajikistan with the assault.

item.title: Takeaways From a Trove of ByteDance Records
item.description: The records briefly surfaced in a lawsuit involving the Republican megadonor Jeff Yass’s firm.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl
item.media:description: The ByteDance offices in Shanghai last year.

item.title: How France Is Fighting ‘Shrinkflation’
item.description: Merchants will be required to put signs in front of all products that have been reduced in size without a corresponding price cut.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Magali Cohen/Hans Lucas, via Reuters Connect
item.media:description: At a Carrefour supermarket in Paris, orange signs indicate snacks that have been downsized.

item.title: Chinese Export Surge Clouds U.S. Hopes of a Domestic Solar Boom
item.description: The decision by a Massachusetts solar company to abandon plans to build a $1.4 billion U.S. factory highlights the risks amid a flood of Chinese clean energy exports.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: A surge of cheap solar panels from China is posing problems for American manufacturers and the Biden administration’s plans to jumpstart U.S. manufacturing.

item.title: Why Don’t More People Resent Manchester City?
item.description: Out of the Champions League but on top of the Premier League, Manchester City shows that it takes more than trophies to make a villain.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: The five trophies won by Manchester City in 2023. Don’t worry, they have more in the back.

item.title: Iran-Israel Shadow War Timeline: A History of Recent Hostilities
item.description: A recent round of strikes has brought the conflict more clearly into the open and raised fears of a broader war.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners in Tehran carried the coffin of Brig. Gen. Sayyed Razi Mousavi, a senior adviser to Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps who was killed in an alleged Israeli airstrike in Syria in 2023.

item.title: Drones Believed to Have Been Used in Iran Attack Are a Common Israeli Weapon
item.description: Iranian officials said that an attack Friday used small drones possibly launched from inside Iran, and that radar systems had not detected unidentified aircraft entering Iranian airspace.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: This satellite image from Planet Labs PBC shows damage on the roof of an Iranian military workshop, center, after a drone attack in Isfahan, Iran, Feb. 2, 2023.

item.title: Israel’s Strike Was Smaller Than Expected, and So Was Iran’s Reaction
item.description: The relatively limited scope of the attack, as well as a muted response from Iranian officials, may have lowered the chances of an immediate escalation, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural of missiles in Tehran celebrating Iran’s attack against Israel on Wednesday.

item.title: What We Know About Israel’s Strike in Iran
item.description: Israel struck Iran early Friday, according to officials from both countries, in what appeared to be its first military response to the Iranian attack on Israel last weekend.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poster depicting missiles in Tehran on Thursday.

item.title: Isfahan Is Home to Iranian Missile and Nuclear Facilities
item.description: Missiles are produced near the city, which also has nuclear research centers.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Visitors at the Si-o-Se Pol bridge in Isfahan last year.

item.title: The Magnetic Heart of the Milky Way
item.description: A new map of the center of the Milky Way galaxy reveals details of its magnetic fields
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Reaction to Israel’s Strike in Iran Plays Down Significance
item.description: In Israel, officials described the strike as a limited response and reports from both sides suggested it did not appear to cause significant damage to military sites.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Farnaz Fassihi and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: Iranian state media showing what it said was a live picture of Isfahan early on Friday.

item.title: What I Learned From an Act of Violence in Sydney That Hit Too Close to Home
item.description: Amid early tidbits of misinformation came lessons about dodging falsities and allowing facts to build a story.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial to victims of the stabbing attack in a Sydney shopping mall.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Israel strikes Iran.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Iranian soldiers marched in front of the Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi (C) during the annual Army Day celebration on Tuesday.

item.title: Apple Says It Was Ordered to Pull WhatsApp From China App Store
item.description: Apple said it removed WhatsApp and Threads from its China app offerings Friday on Beijing’s orders, amid technological tensions between the U.S. and China.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: A recently-opened Apple Store in Shanghai’s Jing’an district in March. Apple said it removed WhatsApp and Threads, which are owned by Meta, from its app store in China.

item.title: U.S. and Allies Penalize Iran for Striking Israel, and Try to Avert War
item.description: While imposing sanctions on Iran, U.S. and European governments are urging restraint amid fears of a cycle of escalation as Israel weighs retaliation for an Iranian attack.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Iranian medium-range missiles during the annual Army Day celebration at a military base in Tehran on Wednesday. The United States imposed sanctions on Iranian armed forces and weapon makers.

item.title: U.S. Vetoes Palestinian Bid to Be Full U.N. Member State
item.description: The move blocked a resolution to support a status that Palestinians had long sought at the United Nations, where it is considered a “nonmember observer state.”
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.media:description: The United Nations Security Council met in New York on Thursday to address issues in the Middle East, including the Palestinian bid for statehood.

item.title: Friday Briefing: India’s Election Begins
item.description: Also, new Western sanctions on Iran, and China’s sinking cities.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: These Indian polling officials took a boat to a remote polling location.

item.title: C.I.A. Director Blames Hamas for Stalled Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: The group’s rejection of a recent proposal “is standing in the way of innocent civilians in Gaza getting humanitarian relief,” the director said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Jerusalem this month calling for the release of hostages held by Hamas.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon’s Husband Charged in Embezzlement Case in Scotland
item.description: Peter Murrell was charged in connection with embezzlement of funds from the Scottish National Party, which his wife once led and where he held a senior role.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Peter Murrell became the Scottish National Party’s chief executive in 1999 and married Nicola Sturgeon, who went on to become its leader, in 2010.

item.title: South Africa’s 2024 National Election: What to Know
item.description: The ruling African National Congress party could lose its parliamentary majority for the first time since the fall of apartheid 30 years ago.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon

item.title: Satellite Data Reveals Sinking Risk for China’s Cities
item.description: Development and groundwater pumping are causing land subsidence and heightening the risks of sea level rise.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sidewalk construction in Tianjin. Last year thousands of residents were evacuated from apartments in the city after nearby streets split apart.

item.title: Land Under B.L.M. Management to Get New Protections
item.description: The measure elevates conservation in a number of ways, including by creating new leases for the restoration of degraded areas.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: Interior Secretary Deb Haaland in 2021. She said the new rule announced on Thursday “helps restore balance to our public lands.”

item.title: Scotland Pauses Gender Medications for Minors
item.description: The change followed a sweeping review by England’s National Health Service that found “remarkably weak” evidence for youth gender treatments.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi
item.media:description: The Sandyford Central Gender Services clinic in Glasgow, Scotland.

item.title: Amsterdam’s Latest Effort to Fight Excessive Tourism: No New Hotels
item.description: The city wants no more than 20 million hotel stays annually. The measure is one of multiple efforts to control the flow of visitors.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A hotel in Amsterdam’s red-light district, where the city has tried to limit crowds.

item.title: Chinese Exports Are Threatening Biden’s Industrial Agenda
item.description: The president is increasingly hitting back with tariffs and other measures meant to restrict imports, raising tensions with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m not looking for a fight with China,” President Biden said during a visit to the United Steelworkers Union in Pittsburgh on Wednesday. “I’m looking for competition — and fair competition.”

item.title: How Israel’s Conflicts Could Escalate
item.description: Israel’s military is dealing with clashes with Hezbollah in Lebanon and with Iran, as well as the continuing war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians on Monday expressing support for their government’s missile and drone attack on Israel over the weekend.

item.title: Prince Harry Now Officially Resident in U.S., Documents Show
item.description: For years, Harry and his wife, Meghan, have considered California home. This week, he updated his residency in a corporate filing.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, were in Florida on Friday. The online filing dated his U.S. residency to June 2023.

item.title: Qatar Says It Is Reviewing Its Mediator Role as Israel-Hamas Talks Stall
item.description: U.S. and Israeli officials have urged the Gulf state to exert more pressure on the Palestinian armed group to reach a deal.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: The Qatari prime minister, right, with the foreign minister of Turkey, at a news conference in Doha, Qatar, this week.

item.title: Millions of Girls in Africa Will Miss HPV Shots After Merck Production Problem
item.description: The company has told countries that it can supply only 18.8 million of the 29.6 million doses it was contracted to deliver this year.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: On the way to class in Freetown, Sierra Leone. The delayed vaccines means that girls in countries such as Sierra Leone, Burkina Faso and Mozambique who are now 14 will no longer be eligible for vaccination when these campaigns finally start.

item.title: Croatia’s Election Result Makes a Far-Right Party a Possible Kingmaker
item.description: The Homeland Movement came third in parliamentary elections, setting itself up as a possible partner for the ruling conservatives, who failed to achieve a majority.
item.dc:creator: Joe Orovic and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: The inconclusive outcome of the parliamentary vote on Wednesday signaled a new era of messy political uncertainty in the Balkan nation

item.title: After Months of Cocaine Washing Ashore, Australian Police Make an Arrest
item.description: Drug parcels kept showing up on beaches along Australia’s shoreline. Now, the police say they found the man behind the botched shipment.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: W.H.O. Broadens Definition of Airborne Diseases
item.description: After a drawn-out global controversy over the coronavirus, the W.H.O. has updated its classification of how pathogens spread through the air.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Drought Pushes Millions Into ‘Acute Hunger’ in Southern Africa
item.description: The disaster, intensified by El Niño, is devastating communities across several countries, killing crops and livestock and sending food prices soaring.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: A farmer in Zimbabwe last month. Several countries have declared national emergencies.

item.title: A Japanese Village Wants Tourists to Come for Heat, Soot and Steel
item.description: To lure visitors, residents of Yoshida, famed for its high-quality steel, are inviting tourists to help produce it.
item.dc:creator: Craig Mod

item.title: An ISIS Terror Group Draws Half Its Recruits From Tiny Tajikistan
item.description: Young migrants from the former Soviet republic were accused of an attack on a concert hall in Moscow that killed 145 people.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Muyasser Zargarova, the mother of one of the Tajik suspects in the terrorist attack outside Moscow, said her son had never exhibited signs of extremism.

item.title: The E.U. says it will impose new sanctions on Iran’s drone and missile programs.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Charles Michel, president of the European Council, at an E.U. summit in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Europe asks Israel for restraint on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Members of the Israeli military showing the remnants of an Iranian ballistic missile that fell on Israel over the weekend.

item.title: Björn Höcke of the AfD Goes on Trial in Germany
item.description: Björn Höcke, one of the most prominent far-right figures in Germany, has called the trial an attempt to suppress patriotism.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Björn Höcke heads the far-right Alternative for Germany party in the state of Thuringia.

item.title: How A.I. Tools Could Change India’s Elections
item.description: Avatars are addressing voters by name, in whichever of India’s many languages they speak. Experts see potential for misuse in a country already rife with disinformation.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Ahmer Khan for The New York Times

item.title: Dubai Flooding Photos and Video: Heavy Rains in UAE and Oman Kill at Least 19
item.description: The heavy rains also flooded parts of Dubai International Airport, causing scores of flight delays and cancellations, and brought other cities in the U.A.E. to a standstill.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: Sheikh Zayed Road highway in Dubai, United Arab Emirates was flooded and shut down following the heaviest rain recorded in the country.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Israel Seems Poised to Retaliate
item.description: Also, a deadly Russian missile strike in Ukraine and “green Islam” in Indonesia.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ilia Yefimovich/picture-alliance, via dpa, via Associated Press Images
item.media:description: The top diplomats from Germany and Britain met with the Israeli president, Isaac Herzog (middle), in Jerusalem yesterday.

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel Will Make Its Own Decisions in Response to Iran’s Attack
item.description: “We will make our own decisions,” said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, rebuffing European diplomats’ requests to stand down.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Members of the Israeli military showing the remnants of an Iranian ballistic missile that fell on Israel over the weekend.

item.title: U.S. Reimposes Oil Sanctions on Venezuela as Hopes Dim for Free Election
item.description: The Biden administration had temporarily lifted sanctions after President Nicolás Maduro agreed to make free elections possible. Now Mr. Maduro has put up barriers to a credible vote.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro after signing up as a candidate for Venezuela’s presidential elections.

item.title: How London Became a ‘Hot Spot’ for Threats Against Iranian Journalists
item.description: Iranian reporters and broadcasters in Britain have suffered physical attacks, threats and surveillance, a report by Reporters Without Borders said, weeks after a newscaster was stabbed in London.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Mount Ruang Volcano Erupts in Indonesia, Forcing Hundreds to Evacuate
item.description: Hundreds of earthquakes were detected in the weeks preceding the eruption of the volcano in North Sulawesi province. Hundreds of people were evacuated.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.category: State University of New York at Buffalo

item.title: Long-Acting Drugs May Revolutionize H.I.V. Prevention and Treatment
item.description: New regimens in development, including once-weekly pills and semiannual shots, could help control the virus in hard-to-reach populations.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kenneth Davis, a patient in an H.I.V. treatment trial, undergoes a routine exam with the assistance of Phoebe Bryson-Cahn, a research clinician, at Harborview Medical Center in Seattle.
